trans-unit.source: Manage your virtual machines by using Azure PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage your virtual machines by using Azure PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn commands that you can use to automate tasks in managing your virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Learn commands that you can use to automate tasks in managing your virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Manage your virtual machines by using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Manage your virtual machines by using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Many tasks you do each day to manage your VMs can be automated by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Many tasks you do each day to manage your VMs can be automated by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: This article gives you example commands for simpler tasks, and links to articles that show the commands for more complex tasks.
trans-unit.target: This article gives you example commands for simpler tasks, and links to articles that show the commands for more complex tasks.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't installed and configured Azure PowerShell yet, you can get instructions in the article <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't installed and configured Azure PowerShell yet, you can get instructions in the article <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: How to use the example commands
trans-unit.target: How to use the example commands

trans-unit.source: You'll need to replace some of the text in the commands with text that's appropriate for your environment. The < and > symbols indicate text you need to replace. When you replace the text, remove the symbols but leave the quote marks in place.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to replace some of the text in the commands with text that's appropriate for your environment. The < and > symbols indicate text you need to replace. When you replace the text, remove the symbols but leave the quote marks in place.

trans-unit.source: Get a VM
trans-unit.target: Get a VM

trans-unit.source: This is a basic task you'll use often.
trans-unit.target: This is a basic task you'll use often.

trans-unit.source: Use it to get information about a VM, perform tasks on a VM, or get output to store in a variable.
trans-unit.target: Use it to get information about a VM, perform tasks on a VM, or get output to store in a variable.

trans-unit.source: To get information about the VM, run this command, replacing everything in the quotes, including the < and > characters:

trans-unit.target: To store the output in a $vm variable, run:

trans-unit.source: Log on to a Windows-based VM
trans-unit.target: Log on to a Windows-based VM

trans-unit.source: Run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Run these commands:

trans-unit.source: You can get the virtual machine and cloud service name from the display of the Get-AzureVM command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the virtual machine and cloud service name from the display of the Get-AzureVM command.

trans-unit.source: $svcName="<html></html>"
trans-unit.target: $svcName="<html></html>"

trans-unit.source: $vmName="<html></html>"
trans-unit.target: $vmName="<html></html>"

trans-unit.source: $localPath="<html></html>"
trans-unit.target: $localPath="<html></html>"

trans-unit.source: $localFile=$localPath + "\" + $vmname + ".rdp"
trans-unit.target: $localFile=$localPath + "\" + $vmname + ".rdp"

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile -ServiceName $svcName -Name $vmName -LocalPath $localFile -Launch
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile -ServiceName $svcName -Name $vmName -LocalPath $localFile -Launch

trans-unit.target: Run this command:

trans-unit.source: Use this parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service. <html></html><html></html> If you use the StayProvisioned parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.
trans-unit.target: Use this parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service. <html></html><html></html> If you use the StayProvisioned parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Attach a data disk
trans-unit.target: Attach a data disk

trans-unit.source: This task requires a few steps.
trans-unit.target: This task requires a few steps.

trans-unit.source: First, you use the **Add-AzureDataDisk** cmdlet to add the disk to the $vm object.
trans-unit.target: First, you use the **Add-AzureDataDisk** cmdlet to add the disk to the $vm object.

trans-unit.source: Then, you use Update-AzureVM cmdlet to update the configuration of the VM.
trans-unit.target: Then, you use Update-AzureVM cmdlet to update the configuration of the VM.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.

trans-unit.source: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it.
trans-unit.target: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it.

trans-unit.source: To attach a new disk, run this command:
trans-unit.target: To attach a new disk, run this command:

trans-unit.target: To attach an existing data disk, run this command:

trans-unit.target: To attach data disks from an existing .vhd file in blob storage, run this command:
